awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Chemical treatment efficiency of point-of-use filters deployed in Flint, Michigan
awd_abstract_narration:
1633013
McElmurry

Changes in the source and treatment of Flint's drinking water have resulted in extensive corrosion and numerous violations to the Safe Drinking Water Act through elevated lead concentrations. As a measure of protection to consumers, faucet-mounted point-of-use filters are being deployed across the city at a scale not previously seen in the United States. The point-of-use filters distributed in Flint are rated for a maximum lead concentration of 150 ppb; however, concentrations of more than 40 times that were observed in January 2016. Therefore, there is an immediate need to rapidly evaluate the treatment efficiency of PoU filters. This Rapid Response Research (RAPID) grant provides a unique opportunity to advance fundamental scientific knowledge regarding physical-chemical process responsible for lead and DBP removal while simultaneously ensuring public health. Controlled laboratory experiments will be conducted to determine treatment efficiency under the range of conditions observed in Flint. These results will be compared to those obtained from filters in homes where filters are subjected to typical use conditions that often deviate significantly from conditions used to certify chemical removal efficiency.

Studies will be conducted to evaluate two hypotheses: (1) lead and copper removal by the ion exchange resin will be reduced by competition from other cations and dissolved organic matter present in Flint drinking water, and, (2) adsorption of trihalomethanes on the activated carbon filtration media will decrease with increasing disinfectant dosage. This work will advance the understanding of the removal of lead, copper and disinfection by-products under real world conditions where complex interactions with colloids and dissolved organic matter occur. The work will utilize controlled laboratory experiments, conducted in state-of-the-art facilities at two major research universities (Wayne State University and Michigan State University) with a strong commitment to collaborative and innovative research. The proposed study will help protect human health and improve the security of municipal water supplies. Laboratory experiments and field sampling will be done in collaboration with Michigan State University and University of Michigan, focused on microbial conditions within point-of-use filters. Results of this study will be disseminated with the assistance of another faculty at Wayne State University, whose research focuses on translating scientific information to the public. Graduate and undergraduate students from groups underrepresented in science and engineering will conduct experiments and collect field samples providing hands on training in the areas of water treatment, colloid chemistry, and disinfection processes. Skills these students obtain will be invaluable in advancing the protection of the nation's water supply. Additionally, the project team will develop and provide lectures and special programs on issues related to aging infrastructure and corrosion control that will be presented at regional meetings of the American Water Works Association.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this RAPID grant was to evaluate the chemical performance point-of-use (PoU) filters deployed in Flint, Michigan. From July 6, 2016 through October 28, 2016, we performed 32 sampling events representing 17 homes where most homes were resampled 2 to 4 weeks after their initial sampling. The filters performed as expected in removing the chemical constituents for which they are certified. Total lead was removed to below detection for all samples. Copper was removed to less than 2.9 μ/L for all samples. The majority of lead entering the filter was particulate, while the opposite was true of copper. The lead concentration was reduced by 77.2 + 0.10% upon filtration through a 0.2 μm polypropylene membrane while the concentration of copper was reduced by only 15.1 + 0.05%. The PoU devices were also effective at removing TTHMs to below detection (~1.5 μg/L).

Removal of these constituents is consistent with the NSF/ANSI certification the filters received and other studies in Flint by the USEPA. These results demonstrate that the activated carbon block PoU filters used in Flint effectively removed the chemicals that drove their deployment in Flint. The PoU filters also removed free chlorine residual (an aesthetic treatment objective) and reduced organic carbon levels, even though neither was a goal of the filter deployment program in Flint. Residual free chlorine was removed from filter effluents to below 0.2 mg Cl2/L in all filtered water samples. Twenty-one states set a disinfectant residual of at least 0.2 mg/L free chlorine in the distribution system. The average concentration of free chlorine entering homes from the distribution system was 0.82 + 0.14 mg Cl2/L (measured at kitchen faucet, bypassing the PoU filter after 5 min of flushing); however, in 4 of 32 sampling events, the free chlorine concentration in these samples was below 0.2 mg Cl2/L.

The removal of free chlorine by the PoU filters was accompanied by the accumulation of organic carbon that serves as a food source for bacterial growth. The average TOC decreased across the filter (p < 0.002); the first-flush concentration entering filters correlated strongly with the concentration leaving the filters (r=0.93). The destruction of chlorine by the activated carbon block PoU filters and the presence of organic carbon pose a challenge when the filters are used as the sole point-of-use treatment strategy; namely, they create a low or disinfectant-free activated carbon surface with a significant organic carbon capture capacity that can support bacterial colonization, consistent with what we observed in Flint.

In controlled laboratory experiments conducted in the ECRL at WSU, the effect of flushing time on bacterial counts in filtered water was determined using GLWA drinking water. Results showed that intact cell concentrations coming out of activated carbon block PoU filters were initially higher in all but one test date and decreased to a stable concentration relatively quickly. The steady state rate at which intact cells leave the filter after 1 minute of filtration increased at approximately 5,600 intact cells per second each day the filter ages (r2 = 0.84) for at least the first 30 days of filter operation. The results suggest that the filters play a role in supporting growth of bacteria over time and that the longer a cartridge is in use, the higher bacterial cell counts will be in filtered water.

Manufacturers recommend that PoU users flush filters for approximately 5 seconds prior to first use after filters have sat unused for at least a few hours.  We conducted a flush study to evaluate how flushing affects microbial water quality over almost 3 months and recommend a slightly longer flushing time (15 seconds).  Our results also show that the bacterial count consistently increases over time. Therefore, it is important to replace PoU cartridges according to manufacturer recommendations.   Finally, in controlled laboratory experiments, the mass of lead entering PoU cartridges was found to correlate (r2 = 0.78) to the mass of lead recovered from the activated carbon present in the PoU core.

Results from sample events conducted in 2016 were mailed or hand delivered to all residents in writing by Thanksgiving 2016, and preliminary results from sample events in March 2017 were verbally reported to residents in April 2017 and final results will be provided in writing to those residents as soon as they are available. Depersonalized results across all monitored homes were shared with residents at a town hall meeting in December 2016, and final results will be compiled in a report that will be sent to all residents as soon as they are compiled and available.  Furthermore, depersonalized results have been shared with public health officials associated with the City of Flint, Genesee County, the State of Michigan, a Physicians group in Genesee County, and the Environmental Protection Agency.
